description.raw:
Add the cable model for task 2.

* The cable is placed in such a way that it starts laying on top of the solar array from pull request #41. It starts in a zig-zag configuration

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3509746750-cable1_small.png)

* The cable is composed of 16 cylindrical links connected by universal joints, plus a spherical link attached to the array.
* All collisions are simple shapes
* The mass of each link is 50 g, so the whole cable weighs `50 * 17 == 0.85 kg`

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3635023652-cable4.png)

* If the inertias for each link were calculated based on a cylinder, they end up being too small and the physics gets a bit crazy. So I capped the minimum value for the inertial components to be 0.0001, which results on inertias larger than the shape of the cable.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2082347044-cable5.png)

* The cable is long enough to reach the other end of the array

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/92030115-cable2.png)

* Surface properties have been chosen so they match other models
description.html:
Add the cable model for task 2.

  • The cable is placed in such a way that it starts laying on top of the solar array from pull request #41. It starts in a zig-zag configuration

  • The cable is composed of 16 cylindrical links connected by universal joints, plus a spherical link attached to the array.
  • All collisions are simple shapes
  • The mass of each link is 50 g, so the whole cable weighs 50 * 17 == 0.85 kg

  • If the inertias for each link were calculated based on a cylinder, they end up being too small and the physics gets a bit crazy. So I capped the minimum value for the inertial components to be 0.0001, which results on inertias larger than the shape of the cable.

  • The cable is long enough to reach the other end of the array

  • Surface properties have been chosen so they match other models
